Reading Complete pages 196-199 in the My View book The story this week is 'Why sun & moon live in the sky. It is a Myth. Please watch the video until you understand the story. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BSAknmmJv1M Complete the definition paper before WEDNESDAY. The spelling test for this FRIDAY is the following words: atmosphere brilliant convince endure glance harsh plunge precious swift unite Let‚Äôs Make Our Own Origin Myth! üåè‚ú® Today, we found the title of our origin Myth 1) Jenny - Why did people choose Earth 2) Ian C - Why the elephant has a long trunk 3) Jason - Why are monkeys so smart 4) Jiwoo - Why Orcas are strong and black 5) Jey - How the starts twinkle 6) Noah - Why the Komodo Dragon has strong poison 7) Yujoo - Why - Why are foxes organge 8) Stells - Why do squid have long legs 9) Wj - Why are monkeys swift 10) Siwoo - Why are turtles so slow 11) Ian S - Why does the sun come out in the morning 12) Alex - Why do sea otters wrap seaweed around their bodies Today, everyone chose a great title for their origin myth ‚Äî well done! For homework, please make a rough draft of your story. You will share it with your friends tomorrow after we read together in class. Your story should explain how or why something began ‚Äî just like the myths we‚Äôve been reading. Be creative and make sure your story has a beginning, middle, and ending. After we share, you‚Äôll make your final version on a poster to display on our classroom windows! Can‚Äôt wait to read your ideas tomorrow, Grade 3 storytellers! üåü Example Origin Myths How the Firefly Got Its Light Once, deep in a rainforest dripping with rain and echoing with frogs, there lived a tiny gray beetle who was always ignored. The butterflies showed off their colors, and the bees buzzed proudly about their honey, but the little beetle had nothing special. One night, as he sat sadly by a puddle, a falling star splashed beside him. ‚ÄúYou look dim,‚Äù said the star kindly. ‚ÄúWould you like a bit of my shine?‚Äù The beetle nodded shyly, and the star touched his back. Suddenly, a golden glow burst from the beetle‚Äôs tail! He flew into the night, lighting the forest like a tiny lantern. From that night on, he shared his light with others who felt unseen‚Äîand that‚Äôs how fireflies came to sparkle across the dark forests every summer night. Why Zebras Have Stripes Long ago, zebras were plain white and loved to roll in the mud. One hot day, a zebra found a cool, shiny black rock and lay down on it to rest. When he stood up, black lines covered his back! The other zebras thought he looked amazing and wanted lines too. They rolled and rolled across the rock until their bodies were covered in black stripes. Ever since then, zebras have worn their stripes proudly under the sun. Why the Parrot Has Bright Feathers Long ago, all parrots were gray and dull. They lived quietly in the jungle trees, afraid of being noticed. One day, Rainbow, the sky painter, flew over the forest with buckets of color. She was in such a hurry to finish painting the sunset that she tripped over a tall tree‚Äîand Red, yellow, green, and blue paint rained down on the parrots below! The parrots gasped when they saw their shiny new feathers. They squawked and danced and showed off their bright colors to every animal in the jungle. Rainbow laughed and said, ‚ÄúYou wear my colors better than the sky!‚Äù And ever since that day, parrots have been the most colorful birds in the world. Science We had a fun time today experimenting with balloons and learning about electrical forces! The students did a great job discovering how objects can attract or repel each other.
